cluster_classes.class_description: Forms of coercive or harmful actions, such as repression and violence, used to control, silence, or intimidate people.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: repression and violence by authorities seeking to maintain their grip on power

members.entity_description: Use of restrictive or coercive measures to control or silence dissent.
Physical force used to harm, damage, or intimidate people.

cluster_classes.class_description: Episodes where governments use force to suppress protests or pro-democracy movements, such as Tiananmen and the Belarus crackdown.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: from the Tiananmen Square massacre in China to the crackdown on pro-democracy protesters in Belarus, governments have used force

members.entity_description: Chinese government’s violent suppression of protesters in Beijing’s Tiananmen Square in 1989.

members.entity_name: crackdown on pro-democracy protesters in Belarus
members.entity_description: Government suppression of demonstrators advocating democracy in Belarus.

cluster_classes.class_description: Sovereign countries that serve as the setting and governing authority for described political events.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Tiananmen Square massacre in China ... crackdown on pro-democracy protesters in Belarus

members.entity_description: Country in East Asia where the Tiananmen Square massacre occurred.
Eastern European country where authorities cracked down on pro-democracy protesters.

cluster_classes.class_description: References to the same sovereign country in North America, officially known as the United States of America.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Country in North America; context includes civil rights and Black Lives Matter movements in the United States.

members.entity_description: Country in which the civil rights movement described in the text took place.
A country in North America, officially known as the United States of America.

args.new_description: All sovereign states (e.g., China, Belarus, the United States) that serve as settings or actors in the described political events.
args.justification: Both classes contain sovereign states referenced as geopolitical contexts for events, so they redundantly model the same concept of countries mentioned in the corpus.
The merged class represents sovereign states; assigning a shared Class_Group clarifies that it is part of a broader schema of geopolitical entities.
This class groups abstract coercive measures like repression and violence, which belong in a broader group covering political repression and state violence phenomena.
This class models concrete events of state repression (e.g., Tiananmen, Belarus crackdown) and should share a Class_Group with the related coercive control phenomena.

executed_decisions.justification: Both classes contain sovereign states referenced as geopolitical contexts for events, so they redundantly model the same concept of countries mentioned in the corpus.
The merged class represents sovereign states; assigning a shared Class_Group clarifies that it is part of a broader schema of geopolitical entities.
This class groups abstract coercive measures like repression and violence, which belong in a broader group covering political repression and state violence phenomena.
This class models concrete events of state repression (e.g., Tiananmen, Belarus crackdown) and should share a Class_Group with the related coercive control phenomena.
